column4: question: how do i set permission access on network devices? i was looking for the /dev/eth0... but obviously it's not there now...
what do you mean "bind to the interface"?
any user can create a socket on the ephemeral (>1024) ports -- for the lower ones, only root can.
but then again, sockets don't really have much to do with the interfaces
thanks, i figured that out too
i was thinking simplist... like just setting chmod 600 on the device... but it seems that is not possible
well, that doesn't make sense - most users on a networked computer require some sort of network connectivity
right, but not if there are two interfaces... they just need access to one
i want to block out the other from being accessed
maybe, i dunno - depends on your setup
well, do any of your users use the other interface at all? you could take the interface down if not.
yes, local users use one interface, and subnet users use another interface
i want to prevent local users from opening sockets on the subnet interface
I would use iptables for this purpose

that's the point.... if i have two seperate rule chains for local users, and one for the subnet, the local user can just bind a socket to the subnet interface and bypass the rules for the local interface
not if you have a rule that prevents traffic from accessing opened sockets tho ..
what do u mean?
let's say you have a rule that drops all packets to the local address unless an outgoing connection is already established - a user may setup a socket, but it will be unusable.
ahh ok i didn't connect that piece when i was setting up my tables... i'll try it out real quick brb
thanks, that cleared up that part
the socket is bound to the iface address, but no connects are accepted because of the table rule
yea, that's the idea exactly
